prop.name: generated-by
prop.value: Cybersecurity And Privacy Open Reference Datasets In OSCAL (CAPORDINO)

prop.name: keywords
prop.value: Critical infrastructure, cybersecurity, information security, information system, OSCAL, Open Security Controls Assessment Language, security functions, security requirements, system, system security

party.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology

address.addr-line: National Institute of Standards and Technology

party.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology

address.addr-line: National Institute of Standards and Technology

part.name: overview
part.p: The organization's cybersecurity risk management strategy, expectations, and policy are established, communicated, and monitored

part.name: statement
part.p: The circumstances - mission, stakeholder expectations, dependencies, and legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements - surrounding the organization's cybersecurity risk management decisions are understood

part.name: statement
part.p: The organizational mission is understood and informs cybersecurity risk management

part.name: example
part.p: Share the organization's mission (e.g., through vision and mission statements, marketing, and service strategies) to provide a basis for identifying risks that may impede that mission

part.name: statement
part.p: Internal and external stakeholders are understood, and their needs and expectations regarding cybersecurity risk management are understood and considered

part.name: example
part.p: Identify relevant internal stakeholders and their cybersecurity-related expectations (e.g., performance and risk expectations of officers, directors, and advisors; cultural expectations of employees)

part.name: example
part.p: Identify relevant external stakeholders and their cybersecurity-related expectations (e.g., privacy expectations of customers, business expectations of partnerships, compliance expectations of regulators, ethics expectations of society)

part.name: statement
part.p: Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements regarding cybersecurity - including privacy and civil liberties obligations - are understood and managed

part.name: example
part.p: Determine a process to track and manage legal and regulatory requirements regarding protection of individuals' information (e.g., Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, California Consumer Privacy Act, General Data Protection Regulation)

part.name: example
part.p: Determine a process to track and manage contractual requirements for cybersecurity management of supplier, customer, and partner information

part.name: example
part.p: Align the organization's cybersecurity strategy with legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements

part.name: statement
part.p: Critical objectives, capabilities, and services that external stakeholders depend on or expect from the organization are understood and communicated

part.name: example
part.p: Establish criteria for determining the criticality of capabilities and services as viewed by internal and external stakeholders

part.name: example
part.p: Determine (e.g., from a business impact analysis) assets and business operations that are vital to achieving mission objectives and the potential impact of a loss (or partial loss) of such operations

part.name: example
part.p: Establish and communicate resilience objectives (e.g., recovery time objectives) for delivering critical capabilities and services in various operating states (e.g., under attack, during recovery, normal operation)

part.name: statement
part.p: Outcomes, capabilities, and services that the organization depends on are understood and communicated

part.name: example
part.p: Create an inventory of the organization's dependencies on external resources (e.g., facilities, cloud-based hosting providers) and their relationships to organizational assets and business functions

part.name: example
part.p: Identify and document external dependencies that are potential points of failure for the organization's critical capabilities and services, and share that information with appropriate personnel

part.name: statement
part.p: Results of organization-wide cybersecurity risk management activities and performance are used to inform, improve, and adjust the risk management strategy

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity risk management strategy outcomes are reviewed to inform and adjust strategy and direction

part.name: example
part.p: Measure how well the risk management strategy and risk results have helped leaders make decisions and achieve organizational objectives

part.name: example
part.p: Examine whether cybersecurity risk strategies that impede operations or innovation should be adjusted

part.name: statement
part.p: The cybersecurity risk management strategy is reviewed and adjusted to ensure coverage of organizational requirements and risks

part.name: example
part.p: Review audit findings to confirm whether the existing cybersecurity strategy has ensured compliance with internal and external requirements

part.name: example
part.p: Review the performance oversight of those in cybersecurity-related roles to determine whether policy changes are necessary

part.name: example
part.p: Review strategy in light of cybersecurity incidents

part.name: statement
part.p: Organizational cybersecurity risk management performance is evaluated and reviewed for adjustments needed

part.name: example
part.p: Review key performance indicators (KPIs) to ensure that organization-wide policies and procedures achieve objectives

part.name: example
part.p: Review key risk indicators (KRIs) to identify risks the organization faces, including likelihood and potential impact

part.name: example
part.p: Collect and communicate metrics on cybersecurity risk management with senior leadership

part.name: statement
part.p: Organizational cybersecurity policy is established, communicated, and enforced

part.name: statement
part.p: Policy for managing cybersecurity risks is established based on organizational context, cybersecurity strategy, and priorities and is communicated and enforced

part.name: example
part.p: Create, disseminate, and maintain an understandable, usable risk management policy with statements of management intent, expectations, and direction

part.name: example
part.p: Periodically review policy and supporting processes and procedures to ensure that they align with risk management strategy objectives and priorities, as well as the high-level direction of the cybersecurity policy

part.name: example
part.p: Require approval from senior management on policy

part.name: example
part.p: Communicate cybersecurity risk management policy and supporting processes and procedures across the organization

part.name: example
part.p: Require personnel to acknowledge receipt of policy when first hired, annually, and whenever policy is updated

part.name: statement
part.p: Policy for managing cybersecurity risks is reviewed, updated, communicated, and enforced to reflect changes in requirements, threats, technology, and organizational mission

part.name: example
part.p: Update policy based on periodic reviews of cybersecurity risk management results to ensure that policy and supporting processes and procedures adequately maintain risk at an acceptable level

part.name: example
part.p: Provide a timeline for reviewing changes to the organization's risk environment (e.g., changes in risk or in the organization's mission objectives), and communicate recommended policy updates

part.name: example
part.p: Update policy to reflect changes in legal and regulatory requirements

part.name: example
part.p: Update policy to reflect changes in technology (e.g., adoption of artificial intelligence) and changes to the business (e.g., acquisition of a new business, new contract requirements)

part.name: statement
part.p: The organization's priorities, constraints, risk tolerance and appetite statements, and assumptions are established, communicated, and used to support operational risk decisions

part.name: statement
part.p: Risk management objectives are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders

part.name: example
part.p: Update near-term and long-term cybersecurity risk management objectives as part of annual strategic planning and when major changes occur

part.name: example
part.p: Establish measurable objectives for cybersecurity risk management (e.g., manage the quality of user training, ensure adequate risk protection for industrial control systems)

part.name: example
part.p: Senior leaders agree about cybersecurity objectives and use them for measuring and managing risk and performance

part.name: statement
part.p: Risk appetite and risk tolerance statements are established, communicated, and maintained

part.name: example
part.p: Determine and communicate risk appetite statements that convey expectations about the appropriate level of risk for the organization

part.name: example
part.p: Translate risk appetite statements into specific, measurable, and broadly understandable risk tolerance statements

part.name: example
part.p: Refine organizational objectives and risk appetite periodically based on known risk exposure and residual risk

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity risk management activities and outcomes are included in enterprise risk management processes

part.name: example
part.p: Aggregate and manage cybersecurity risks alongside other enterprise risks (e.g., compliance, financial, operational, regulatory, reputational, safety)

part.name: example
part.p: Include cybersecurity risk managers in enterprise risk management planning

part.name: example
part.p: Establish criteria for escalating cybersecurity risks within enterprise risk management

part.name: statement
part.p: Strategic direction that describes appropriate risk response options is established and communicated

part.name: example
part.p: Specify criteria for accepting and avoiding cybersecurity risk for various classifications of data

part.name: example
part.p: Determine whether to purchase cybersecurity insurance

part.name: example
part.p: Document conditions under which shared responsibility models are acceptable (e.g., outsourcing certain cybersecurity functions, having a third party perform financial transactions on behalf of the organization, using public cloud-based services)

part.name: statement
part.p: Lines of communication across the organization are established for cybersecurity risks, including risks from suppliers and other third parties

part.name: example
part.p: Determine how to update senior executives, directors, and management on the organization's cybersecurity posture at agreed-upon intervals

part.name: example
part.p: Identify how all departments across the organization - such as management, operations, internal auditors, legal, acquisition, physical security, and HR - will communicate with each other about cybersecurity risks

part.name: statement
part.p: A standardized method for calculating, documenting, categorizing, and prioritizing cybersecurity risks is established and communicated

part.name: example
part.p: Establish criteria for using a quantitative approach to cybersecurity risk analysis, and specify probability and exposure formulas

part.name: example
part.p: Create and use templates (e.g., a risk register) to document cybersecurity risk information (e.g., risk description, exposure, treatment, and ownership)

part.name: example
part.p: Establish criteria for risk prioritization at the appropriate levels within the enterprise

part.name: example
part.p: Use a consistent list of risk categories to support integrating, aggregating, and comparing cybersecurity risks

part.name: statement
part.p: Strategic opportunities (i.e., positive risks) are characterized and are included in organizational cybersecurity risk discussions

part.name: example
part.p: Define and communicate guidance and methods for identifying opportunities and including them in risk discussions (e.g., strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats (SWOT) analysis)

part.name: example
part.p: Identify stretch goals and document them

part.name: example
part.p: Calculate, document, and prioritize positive risks alongside negative risks

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity roles, responsibilities, and authorities to foster accountability, performance assessment, and continuous improvement are established and communicated

part.name: statement
part.p: Organizational leadership is responsible and accountable for cybersecurity risk and fosters a culture that is risk-aware, ethical, and continually improving

part.name: example
part.p: Leaders (e.g., directors) agree on their roles and responsibilities in developing, implementing, and assessing the organization's cybersecurity strategy

part.name: example
part.p: Share leaders' expectations regarding a secure and ethical culture, especially when current events present the opportunity to highlight positive or negative examples of cybersecurity risk management

part.name: example
part.p: Leaders direct the CISO to maintain a comprehensive cybersecurity risk strategy and review and update it at least annually and after major events

part.name: example
part.p: Conduct reviews to ensure adequate authority and coordination among those responsible for managing cybersecurity risk

part.name: statement
part.p: Roles, responsibilities, and authorities related to cybersecurity risk management are established, communicated, understood, and enforced

part.name: example
part.p: Document risk management roles and responsibilities in policy

part.name: example
part.p: Document who is responsible and accountable for cybersecurity risk management activities and how those teams and individuals are to be consulted and informed

part.name: example
part.p: Include cybersecurity responsibilities and performance requirements in personnel descriptions

part.name: example
part.p: Document performance goals for personnel with cybersecurity risk management responsibilities, and periodically measure performance to identify areas for improvement

part.name: example
part.p: Clearly articulate cybersecurity responsibilities within operations, risk functions, and internal audit functions

part.name: statement
part.p: Adequate resources are allocated commensurate with the cybersecurity risk strategy, roles, responsibilities, and policies

part.name: example
part.p: Conduct periodic management reviews to ensure that those given cybersecurity risk management responsibilities have the necessary authority

part.name: example
part.p: Identify resource allocation and investment in line with risk tolerance and response

part.name: example
part.p: Provide adequate and sufficient people, process, and technical resources to support the cybersecurity strategy

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices

part.name: example
part.p: Integrate cybersecurity risk management considerations into human resources processes (e.g., personnel screening, onboarding, change notification, offboarding)

part.name: example
part.p: Consider cybersecurity knowledge to be a positive factor in hiring, training, and retention decisions

part.name: example
part.p: Conduct background checks prior to onboarding new personnel for sensitive roles, and periodically repeat background checks for personnel with such roles

part.name: example
part.p: Define and enforce obligations for personnel to be aware of, adhere to, and uphold security policies as they relate to their roles

part.name: statement
part.p: Cyber supply chain risk management processes are identified, established, managed, monitored, and improved by organizational stakeholders

part.name: statement
part.p: A cybersecurity supply chain risk management program, strategy, objectives, policies, and processes are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders

part.name: example
part.p: Establish a strategy that expresses the objectives of the cybersecurity supply chain risk management program

part.name: example
part.p: Develop the cybersecurity supply chain risk management program, including a plan (with milestones), policies, and procedures that guide implementation and improvement of the program, and share the policies and procedures with the organizational stakeholders

part.name: example
part.p: Develop and implement program processes based on the strategy, objectives, policies, and procedures that are agreed upon and performed by the organizational stakeholders

part.name: example
part.p: Establish a cross-organizational mechanism that ensures alignment between functions that contribute to cybersecurity supply chain risk management, such as cybersecurity, IT, operations, legal, human resources, and engineering

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for suppliers, customers, and partners are established, communicated, and coordinated internally and externally

part.name: example
part.p: Identify one or more specific roles or positions that will be responsible and accountable for planning, resourcing, and executing cybersecurity supply chain risk management activities

part.name: example
part.p: Document cybersecurity supply chain risk management roles and responsibilities in policy

part.name: example
part.p: Create responsibility matrixes to document who will be responsible and accountable for cybersecurity supply chain risk management activities and how those teams and individuals will be consulted and informed

part.name: example
part.p: Include cybersecurity supply chain risk management responsibilities and performance requirements in personnel descriptions to ensure clarity and improve accountability

part.name: example
part.p: Document performance goals for personnel with cybersecurity risk management-specific responsibilities, and periodically measure them to demonstrate and improve performance

part.name: example
part.p: Develop roles and responsibilities for suppliers, customers, and business partners to address shared responsibilities for applicable cybersecurity risks, and integrate them into organizational policies and applicable third-party agreements

part.name: example
part.p: Internally communicate cybersecurity supply chain risk management roles and responsibilities for third parties

part.name: example
part.p: Establish rules and protocols for information sharing and reporting processes between the organization and its suppliers

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management is integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management, risk assessment, and improvement processes

part.name: example
part.p: Identify areas of alignment and overlap with cybersecurity and enterprise risk management

part.name: example
part.p: Establish integrated control sets for cybersecurity risk management and cybersecurity supply chain risk management

part.name: example
part.p: Integrate cybersecurity supply chain risk management into improvement processes

part.name: example
part.p: Escalate material cybersecurity risks in supply chains to senior management, and address them at the enterprise risk management level

part.name: statement
part.p: Suppliers are known and prioritized by criticality

part.name: example
part.p: Develop criteria for supplier criticality based on, for example, the sensitivity of data processed or possessed by suppliers, the degree of access to the organization's systems, and the importance of the products or services to the organization's mission

part.name: example
part.p: Keep a record of all suppliers, and prioritize suppliers based on the criticality criteria

part.name: statement
part.p: Requirements to address cybersecurity risks in supply chains are established, prioritized, and integrated into contracts and other types of agreements with suppliers and other relevant third parties

part.name: example
part.p: Establish security requirements for suppliers, products, and services commensurate with their criticality level and potential impact if compromised

part.name: example
part.p: Include all cybersecurity and supply chain requirements that third parties must follow and how compliance with the requirements may be verified in default contractual language

part.name: example
part.p: Define the rules and protocols for information sharing between the organization and its suppliers and sub-tier suppliers in agreements

part.name: example
part.p: Manage risk by including security requirements in agreements based on their criticality and potential impact if compromised

part.name: example
part.p: Define security requirements in service-level agreements (SLAs) for monitoring suppliers for acceptable security performance throughout the supplier relationship lifecycle

part.name: example
part.p: Contractually require suppliers to disclose cybersecurity features, functions, and vulnerabilities of their products and services for the life of the product or the term of service

part.name: example
part.p: Contractually require suppliers to provide and maintain a current component inventory (e.g., software or hardware bill of materials) for critical products

part.name: example
part.p: Contractually require suppliers to vet their employees and guard against insider threats

part.name: example
part.p: Contractually require suppliers to provide evidence of performing acceptable security practices through, for example, self-attestation, conformance to known standards, certifications, or inspections

part.name: example
part.p: Specify in contracts and other agreements the rights and responsibilities of the organization, its suppliers, and their supply chains, with respect to potential cybersecurity risks

part.name: statement
part.p: Planning and due diligence are performed to reduce risks before entering into formal supplier or other third-party relationships

part.name: example
part.p: Perform thorough due diligence on prospective suppliers that is consistent with procurement planning and commensurate with the level of risk, criticality, and complexity of each supplier relationship

part.name: example
part.p: Assess the suitability of the technology and cybersecurity capabilities and the risk management practices of prospective suppliers

part.name: example
part.p: Conduct supplier risk assessments against business and applicable cybersecurity requirements

part.name: example
part.p: Assess the authenticity, integrity, and security of critical products prior to acquisition and use

part.name: statement
part.p: The risks posed by a supplier, their products and services, and other third parties are understood, recorded, prioritized, assessed, responded to, and monitored over the course of the relationship

part.name: example
part.p: Adjust assessment formats and frequencies based on the third party's reputation and the criticality of the products or services they provide

part.name: example
part.p: Evaluate third parties' evidence of compliance with contractual cybersecurity requirements, such as self-attestations, warranties, certifications, and other artifacts

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor critical suppliers to ensure that they are fulfilling their security obligations throughout the supplier relationship lifecycle using a variety of methods and techniques, such as inspections, audits, tests, or other forms of evaluation

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor critical suppliers, services, and products for changes to their risk profiles, and reevaluate supplier criticality and risk impact accordingly

part.name: example
part.p: Plan for unexpected supplier and supply chain-related interruptions to ensure business continuity

part.name: statement
part.p: Relevant suppliers and other third parties are included in incident planning, response, and recovery activities

part.name: example
part.p: Define and use rules and protocols for reporting incident response and recovery activities and the status between the organization and its suppliers

part.name: example
part.p: Identify and document the roles and responsibilities of the organization and its suppliers for incident response

part.name: example
part.p: Include critical suppliers in incident response exercises and simulations

part.name: example
part.p: Define and coordinate crisis communication methods and protocols between the organization and its critical suppliers

part.name: example
part.p: Conduct collaborative lessons learned sessions with critical suppliers

part.name: statement
part.p: Supply chain security practices are integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management programs, and their performance is monitored throughout the technology product and service life cycle

part.name: example
part.p: Policies and procedures require provenance records for all acquired technology products and services

part.name: example
part.p: Periodically provide risk reporting to leaders about how acquired components are proven to be untampered and authentic

part.name: example
part.p: Communicate regularly among cybersecurity risk managers and operations personnel about the need to acquire software patches, updates, and upgrades only from authenticated and trustworthy software providers

part.name: example
part.p: Review policies to ensure that they require approved supplier personnel to perform maintenance on supplier products

part.name: example
part.p: Policies and procedure require checking upgrades to critical hardware for unauthorized changes

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management plans include provisions for activities that occur after the conclusion of a partnership or service agreement

part.name: example
part.p: Establish processes for terminating critical relationships under both normal and adverse circumstances

part.name: example
part.p: Define and implement plans for component end-of-life maintenance support and obsolescence

part.name: example
part.p: Verify that supplier access to organization resources is deactivated promptly when it is no longer needed

part.name: example
part.p: Verify that assets containing the organization's data are returned or properly disposed of in a timely, controlled, and safe manner

part.name: example
part.p: Develop and execute a plan for terminating or transitioning supplier relationships that takes supply chain security risk and resiliency into account

part.name: example
part.p: Mitigate risks to data and systems created by supplier termination

part.name: example
part.p: Manage data leakage risks associated with supplier termination

part.name: overview
part.p: The organization's current cybersecurity risks are understood

part.name: statement
part.p: Assets (e.g., data, hardware, software, systems, facilities, services, people) that enable the organization to achieve business purposes are identified and managed consistent with their relative importance to organizational objectives and the organization's risk strategy

part.name: statement
part.p: Inventories of hardware managed by the organization are maintained

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain inventories for all types of hardware, including IT, IoT, OT, and mobile devices

part.name: example
part.p: Constantly monitor networks to detect new hardware and automatically update inventories

part.name: statement
part.p: Inventories of software, services, and systems managed by the organization are maintained

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain inventories for all types of software and services, including commercial-off-the-shelf, open-source, custom applications, API services, and cloud-based applications and services

part.name: example
part.p: Constantly monitor all platforms, including containers and virtual machines, for software and service inventory changes

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain an inventory of the organization's systems

part.name: statement
part.p: Representations of the organization's authorized network communication and internal and external network data flows are maintained

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain baselines of communication and data flows within the organization's wired and wireless networks

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain baselines of communication and data flows between the organization and third parties

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain baselines of communication and data flows for the organization's infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS) usage

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain documentation of expected network ports, protocols, and services that are typically used among authorized systems

part.name: statement
part.p: Inventories of services provided by suppliers are maintained

part.name: example
part.p: Inventory all external services used by the organization, including third-party infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS), platform-as-a-service (PaaS), and software-as-a-service (SaaS) offerings; APIs; and other externally hosted application services

part.name: example
part.p: Update the inventory when a new external service is going to be utilized to ensure adequate cybersecurity risk management monitoring of the organization's use of that service

part.name: statement
part.p: Assets are prioritized based on classification, criticality, resources, and impact on the mission

part.name: example
part.p: Define criteria for prioritizing each class of assets

part.name: example
part.p: Apply the prioritization criteria to assets

part.name: example
part.p: Track the asset priorities and update them periodically or when significant changes to the organization occur

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for the entire workforce and third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) are established

part.name: statement
part.p: Inventories of data and corresponding metadata for designated data types are maintained

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain a list of the designated data types of interest (e.g., personally identifiable information, protected health information, financial account numbers, organization intellectual property, operational technology data)

part.name: example
part.p: Continuously discover and analyze ad hoc data to identify new instances of designated data types

part.name: example
part.p: Assign data classifications to designated data types through tags or labels

part.name: example
part.p: Track the provenance, data owner, and geolocation of each instance of designated data types

part.name: statement
part.p: Systems, hardware, software, services, and data are managed throughout their life cycles

part.name: example
part.p: Integrate cybersecurity considerations throughout the life cycles of systems, hardware, software, and services

part.name: example
part.p: Integrate cybersecurity considerations into product life cycles

part.name: example
part.p: Identify unofficial uses of technology to meet mission objectives (i.e., shadow IT)

part.name: example
part.p: Periodically identify redundant systems, hardware, software, and services that unnecessarily increase the organization's attack surface

part.name: example
part.p: Properly configure and secure systems, hardware, software, and services prior to their deployment in production

part.name: example
part.p: Update inventories when systems, hardware, software, and services are moved or transferred within the organization

part.name: example
part.p: Securely destroy stored data based on the organization's data retention policy using the prescribed destruction method, and keep and manage a record of the destructions

part.name: example
part.p: Securely sanitize data storage when hardware is being retired, decommissioned, reassigned, or sent for repairs or replacement

part.name: example
part.p: Offer methods for destroying paper, storage media, and other physical forms of data storage

part.name: statement
part.p: The organization’s role in the supply chain is identified and communicated

part.name: statement
part.p: The organization’s place in critical infrastructure and its industry sector is identified and communicated

part.name: statement
part.p: Priorities for organizational mission, objectives, and activities are established and communicated

part.name: statement
part.p: Dependencies and critical functions for delivery of critical services are established

part.name: statement
part.p: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)

part.name: statement
part.p: Organizational cybersecurity policy is established and communicated

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities are coordinated and aligned with internal roles and external partners

part.name: statement
part.p: Legal and regulatory requirements regarding cybersecurity, including privacy and civil liberties obligations, are understood and managed

part.name: statement
part.p: Governance and risk management processes address cybersecurity risks

part.name: statement
part.p: Improvements to organizational cybersecurity risk management processes, procedures and activities are identified across all CSF Functions

part.name: statement
part.p: Improvements are identified from evaluations

part.name: example
part.p: Perform self-assessments of critical services that take current threats and TTPs into consideration

part.name: example
part.p: Invest in third-party assessments or independent audits of the effectiveness of the organization's cybersecurity program to identify areas that need improvement

part.name: example
part.p: Constantly evaluate compliance with selected cybersecurity requirements through automated means

part.name: statement
part.p: Improvements are identified from security tests and exercises, including those done in coordination with suppliers and relevant third parties

part.name: example
part.p: Identify improvements for future incident response activities based on findings from incident response assessments (e.g., tabletop exercises and simulations, tests, internal reviews, independent audits)

part.name: example
part.p: Identify improvements for future business continuity, disaster recovery, and incident response activities based on exercises performed in coordination with critical service providers and product suppliers

part.name: example
part.p: Involve internal stakeholders (e.g., senior executives, legal department, HR) in security tests and exercises as appropriate

part.name: example
part.p: Perform penetration testing to identify opportunities to improve the security posture of selected high-risk systems as approved by leadership

part.name: example
part.p: Exercise contingency plans for responding to and recovering from the discovery that products or services did not originate with the contracted supplier or partner or were altered before receipt

part.name: example
part.p: Collect and analyze performance metrics using security tools and services to inform improvements to the cybersecurity program

part.name: statement
part.p: Improvements are identified from execution of operational processes, procedures, and activities

part.name: example
part.p: Conduct collaborative lessons learned sessions with suppliers

part.name: example
part.p: Annually review cybersecurity policies, processes, and procedures to take lessons learned into account

part.name: example
part.p: Use metrics to assess operational cybersecurity performance over time

part.name: statement
part.p: Incident response plans and other cybersecurity plans that affect operations are established, communicated, maintained, and improved

part.name: example
part.p: Establish contingency plans (e.g., incident response, business continuity, disaster recovery) for responding to and recovering from adverse events that can interfere with operations, expose confidential information, or otherwise endanger the organization's mission and viability

part.name: example
part.p: Include contact and communication information, processes for handling common scenarios, and criteria for prioritization, escalation, and elevation in all contingency plans

part.name: example
part.p: Create a vulnerability management plan to identify and assess all types of vulnerabilities and to prioritize, test, and implement risk responses

part.name: example
part.p: Communicate cybersecurity plans (including updates) to those responsible for carrying them out and to affected parties

part.name: example
part.p: Review and update all cybersecurity plans annually or when a need for significant improvements is identified

part.name: statement
part.p: The cybersecurity risk to the organization, assets, and individuals is understood by the organization

part.name: statement
part.p: Vulnerabilities in assets are identified, validated, and recorded

part.name: example
part.p: Use vulnerability management technologies to identify unpatched and misconfigured software

part.name: example
part.p: Assess network and system architectures for design and implementation weaknesses that affect cybersecurity

part.name: example
part.p: Review, analyze, or test organization-developed software to identify design, coding, and default configuration vulnerabilities

part.name: example
part.p: Assess facilities that house critical computing assets for physical vulnerabilities and resilience issues

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor sources of cyber threat intelligence for information on new vulnerabilities in products and services

part.name: example
part.p: Review processes and procedures for weaknesses that could be exploited to affect cybersecurity

part.name: statement
part.p: Cyber threat intelligence is received from information sharing forums and sources

part.name: example
part.p: Configure cybersecurity tools and technologies with detection or response capabilities to securely ingest cyber threat intelligence feeds

part.name: example
part.p: Receive and review advisories from reputable third parties on current threat actors and their tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs)

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor sources of cyber threat intelligence for information on the types of vulnerabilities that emerging technologies may have

part.name: statement
part.p: Internal and external threats to the organization are identified and recorded

part.name: example
part.p: Use cyber threat intelligence to maintain awareness of the types of threat actors likely to target the organization and the TTPs they are likely to use

part.name: example
part.p: Perform threat hunting to look for signs of threat actors within the environment

part.name: example
part.p: Implement processes for identifying internal threat actors

part.name: statement
part.p: Potential impacts and likelihoods of threats exploiting vulnerabilities are identified and recorded

part.name: example
part.p: Business leaders and cybersecurity risk management practitioners work together to estimate the likelihood and impact of risk scenarios and record them in risk registers

part.name: example
part.p: Enumerate the potential business impacts of unauthorized access to the organization's communications, systems, and data processed in or by those systems

part.name: example
part.p: Account for the potential impacts of cascading failures for systems of systems

part.name: statement
part.p: Threats, vulnerabilities, likelihoods, and impacts are used to understand inherent risk and inform risk response prioritization

part.name: example
part.p: Develop threat models to better understand risks to the data and identify appropriate risk responses

part.name: example
part.p: Prioritize cybersecurity resource allocations and investments based on estimated likelihoods and impacts

part.name: statement
part.p: Risk responses are chosen, prioritized, planned, tracked, and communicated

part.name: example
part.p: Apply the vulnerability management plan's criteria for deciding whether to accept, transfer, mitigate, or avoid risk

part.name: example
part.p: Apply the vulnerability management plan's criteria for selecting compensating controls to mitigate risk

part.name: example
part.p: Track the progress of risk response implementation (e.g., plan of action and milestones (POA&M), risk register, risk detail report)

part.name: example
part.p: Use risk assessment findings to inform risk response decisions and actions

part.name: example
part.p: Communicate planned risk responses to affected stakeholders in priority order

part.name: statement
part.p: Changes and exceptions are managed, assessed for risk impact, recorded, and tracked

part.name: example
part.p: Implement and follow procedures for the formal documentation, review, testing, and approval of proposed changes and requested exceptions

part.name: example
part.p: Document the possible risks of making or not making each proposed change, and provide guidance on rolling back changes

part.name: example
part.p: Document the risks related to each requested exception and the plan for responding to those risks

part.name: example
part.p: Periodically review risks that were accepted based upon planned future actions or milestones

part.name: statement
part.p: Processes for receiving, analyzing, and responding to vulnerability disclosures are established

part.name: example
part.p: Conduct vulnerability information sharing between the organization and its suppliers following the rules and protocols defined in contracts

part.name: example
part.p: Assign responsibilities and verify the execution of procedures for processing, analyzing the impact of, and responding to cybersecurity threat, vulnerability, or incident disclosures by suppliers, customers, partners, and government cybersecurity organizations

part.name: statement
part.p: The authenticity and integrity of hardware and software are assessed prior to acquisition and use

part.name: example
part.p: Assess the authenticity and cybersecurity of critical technology products and services prior to acquisition and use

part.name: statement
part.p: Critical suppliers are assessed prior to acquisition

part.name: example
part.p: Conduct supplier risk assessments against business and applicable cybersecurity requirements, including the supply chain

part.name: statement
part.p: Risk management processes are established, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders

part.name: statement
part.p: Organizational risk tolerance is determined and clearly expressed

part.name: statement
part.p: The organization’s determination of risk tolerance is informed by its role in critical infrastructure and sector specific risk analysis

part.name: statement
part.p: Cyber supply chain risk management processes are identified, established, assessed, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders

part.name: statement
part.p: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process

part.name: statement
part.p: Contracts with suppliers and third-party partners are used to implement appropriate measures designed to meet the objectives of an organization’s cybersecurity program and Cyber Supply Chain Risk Management Plan.

part.name: statement
part.p: Suppliers and third-party partners are routinely assessed using audits, test results, or other forms of evaluations to confirm they are meeting their contractual obligations.

part.name: statement
part.p: Response and recovery planning and testing are conducted with suppliers and third-party providers

part.name: overview
part.p: Safeguards to manage the organization's cybersecurity risks are used

control.title: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control

prop.name: label
prop.value: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control (PR.AA)

part.name: statement
part.p: Access to physical and logical assets is limited to authorized users, services, and hardware and managed commensurate with the assessed risk of unauthorized access

part.name: statement
part.p: Identities and credentials for authorized users, services, and hardware are managed by the organization

part.name: example
part.p: Initiate requests for new access or additional access for employees, contractors, and others, and track, review, and fulfill the requests, with permission from system or data owners when needed

part.name: example
part.p: Issue, manage, and revoke cryptographic certificates and identity tokens, cryptographic keys (i.e., key management), and other credentials

part.name: example
part.p: Select a unique identifier for each device from immutable hardware characteristics or an identifier securely provisioned to the device

part.name: example
part.p: Physically label authorized hardware with an identifier for inventory and servicing purposes

part.name: statement
part.p: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials based on the context of interactions

part.name: example
part.p: Verify a person's claimed identity at enrollment time using government-issued identity credentials (e.g., passport, visa, driver's license)

part.name: example
part.p: Issue a different credential for each person (i.e., no credential sharing)

part.name: statement
part.p: Users, services, and hardware are authenticated

part.name: example
part.p: Require multifactor authentication

part.name: example
part.p: Enforce policies for the minimum strength of passwords, PINs, and similar authenticators

part.name: example
part.p: Periodically reauthenticate users, services, and hardware based on risk (e.g., in zero trust architectures)

part.name: example
part.p: Ensure that authorized personnel can access accounts essential for protecting safety under emergency conditions

part.name: statement
part.p: Identity assertions are protected, conveyed, and verified

part.name: example
part.p: Protect identity assertions that are used to convey authentication and user information through single sign-on systems

part.name: example
part.p: Protect identity assertions that are used to convey authentication and user information between federated systems

part.name: example
part.p: Implement standards-based approaches for identity assertions in all contexts, and follow all guidance for the generation (e.g., data models, metadata), protection (e.g., digital signing, encryption), and verification (e.g., signature validation) of identity assertions

part.name: statement
part.p: Access permissions, entitlements, and authorizations are defined in a policy, managed, enforced, and reviewed, and incorporate the principles of least privilege and separation of duties

part.name: example
part.p: Review logical and physical access privileges periodically and whenever someone changes roles or leaves the organization, and promptly rescind privileges that are no longer needed

part.name: example
part.p: Take attributes of the requester and the requested resource into account for authorization decisions (e.g., geolocation, day/time, requester endpoint's cyber health)

part.name: example
part.p: Restrict access and privileges to the minimum necessary (e.g., zero trust architecture)

part.name: example
part.p: Periodically review the privileges associated with critical business functions to confirm proper separation of duties

part.name: statement
part.p: Physical access to assets is managed, monitored, and enforced commensurate with risk

part.name: example
part.p: Use security guards, security cameras, locked entrances, alarm systems, and other physical controls to monitor facilities and restrict access

part.name: example
part.p: Employ additional physical security controls for areas that contain high-risk assets

part.name: example
part.p: Escort guests, vendors, and other third parties within areas that contain business-critical assets

control.title: Identity Management, Authentication and Access Control

prop.name: label
prop.value: Identity Management, Authentication and Access Control (PR.AC)

part.name: statement
part.p: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes

part.name: statement
part.p: Physical access to assets is managed and protected

part.name: statement
part.p: Remote access is managed

part.name: statement
part.p: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties

part.name: statement
part.p: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)

part.name: statement
part.p: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

part.name: statement
part.p: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals’ security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

part.name: statement
part.p: The organization's personnel are provided with cybersecurity awareness and training so that they can perform their cybersecurity-related tasks

part.name: statement
part.p: Personnel are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform general tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind

part.name: example
part.p: Provide basic cybersecurity awareness and training to employees, contractors, partners, suppliers, and all other users of the organization's non-public resources

part.name: example
part.p: Train personnel to recognize social engineering attempts and other common attacks, report attacks and suspicious activity, comply with acceptable use policies, and perform basic cyber hygiene tasks (e.g., patching software, choosing passwords, protecting credentials)

part.name: example
part.p: Explain the consequences of cybersecurity policy violations, both to individual users and the organization as a whole

part.name: example
part.p: Periodically assess or test users on their understanding of basic cybersecurity practices

part.name: example
part.p: Require annual refreshers to reinforce existing practices and introduce new practices

part.name: statement
part.p: Individuals in specialized roles are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform relevant tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind

part.name: example
part.p: Identify the specialized roles within the organization that require additional cybersecurity training, such as physical and cybersecurity personnel, finance personnel, senior leadership, and anyone with access to business-critical data

part.name: example
part.p: Provide role-based cybersecurity awareness and training to all those in specialized roles, including contractors, partners, suppliers, and other third parties

part.name: example
part.p: Periodically assess or test users on their understanding of cybersecurity practices for their specialized roles

part.name: example
part.p: Require annual refreshers to reinforce existing practices and introduce new practices

part.name: statement
part.p: Third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) understand their roles and responsibilities

part.name: statement
part.p: Senior executives understand their roles and responsibilities

part.name: statement
part.p: Physical and cybersecurity personnel understand their roles and responsibilities

part.name: statement
part.p: Data are managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information

part.name: statement
part.p: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-at-rest are protected

part.name: example
part.p: Use encryption, digital signatures, and cryptographic hashes to protect the confidentiality and integrity of stored data in files, databases, virtual machine disk images, container images, and other resources

part.name: example
part.p: Use full disk encryption to protect data stored on user endpoints

part.name: example
part.p: Confirm the integrity of software by validating signatures

part.name: example
part.p: Restrict the use of removable media to prevent data exfiltration

part.name: example
part.p: Physically secure removable media containing unencrypted sensitive information, such as within locked offices or file cabinets

part.name: statement
part.p: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-transit are protected

part.name: example
part.p: Use encryption, digital signatures, and cryptographic hashes to protect the confidentiality and integrity of network communications

part.name: example
part.p: Automatically encrypt or block outbound emails and other communications that contain sensitive data, depending on the data classification

part.name: example
part.p: Block access to personal email, file sharing, file storage services, and other personal communications applications and services from organizational systems and networks

part.name: example
part.p: Prevent reuse of sensitive data from production environments (e.g., customer records) in development, testing, and other non-production environments

part.name: statement
part.p: Assets are formally managed throughout removal, transfers, and disposition

part.name: statement
part.p: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained

part.name: statement
part.p: Protections against data leaks are implemented

part.name: statement
part.p: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

part.name: statement
part.p: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment

part.name: statement
part.p: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify hardware integrity

part.name: statement
part.p: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-use are protected

part.name: example
part.p: Remove data that must remain confidential (e.g., from processors and memory) as soon as it is no longer needed

part.name: example
part.p: Protect data in use from access by other users and processes of the same platform

part.name: statement
part.p: Backups of data are created, protected, maintained, and tested

part.name: example
part.p: Continuously back up critical data in near-real-time, and back up other data frequently at agreed-upon schedules

part.name: example
part.p: Test backups and restores for all types of data sources at least annually

part.name: example
part.p: Securely store some backups offline and offsite so that an incident or disaster will not damage them

part.name: example
part.p: Enforce geographic separation and geolocation restrictions for data backup storage

part.name: statement
part.p: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)

part.name: statement
part.p: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented

part.name: statement
part.p: Configuration change control processes are in place

part.name: statement
part.p: Backups of information are conducted, maintained, and tested

part.name: statement
part.p: Policy and regulations regarding the physical operating environment for organizational assets are met

part.name: statement
part.p: Data is destroyed according to policy

part.name: statement
part.p: Protection processes are improved

part.name: statement
part.p: Effectiveness of protection technologies is shared

part.name: statement
part.p: Response plans (Incident Response and Business Continuity) and recovery plans (Incident Recovery and Disaster Recovery) are in place and managed

part.name: statement
part.p: Response and recovery plans are tested

part.name: statement
part.p: Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices (e.g., deprovisioning, personnel screening)

part.name: statement
part.p: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

part.name: statement
part.p: Security architectures are managed with the organization's risk strategy to protect asset confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and organizational resilience

part.name: statement
part.p: Networks and environments are protected from unauthorized logical access and usage

part.name: example
part.p: Logically segment organization networks and cloud-based platforms according to trust boundaries and platform types (e.g., IT, IoT, OT, mobile, guests), and permit required communications only between segments

part.name: example
part.p: Logically segment organization networks from external networks, and permit only necessary communications to enter the organization's networks from the external networks

part.name: example
part.p: Implement zero trust architectures to restrict network access to each resource to the minimum necessary

part.name: example
part.p: Check the cyber health of endpoints before allowing them to access and use production resources

part.name: statement
part.p: The organization's technology assets are protected from environmental threats

part.name: example
part.p: Protect organizational equipment from known environmental threats, such as flooding, fire, wind, and excessive heat and humidity

part.name: example
part.p: Include protection from environmental threats and provisions for adequate operating infrastructure in requirements for service providers that operate systems on the organization's behalf

part.name: statement
part.p: Mechanisms are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations

part.name: example
part.p: Avoid single points of failure in systems and infrastructure

part.name: example
part.p: Use load balancing to increase capacity and improve reliability

part.name: example
part.p: Use high-availability components like redundant storage and power supplies to improve system reliability

part.name: statement
part.p: Adequate resource capacity to ensure availability is maintained

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor usage of storage, power, compute, network bandwidth, and other resources

part.name: example
part.p: Forecast future needs, and scale resources accordingly

part.name: statement
part.p: Maintenance and repair of organizational assets are performed and logged, with approved and controlled tools

part.name: statement
part.p: Remote maintenance of organizational assets is approved, logged, and performed in a manner that prevents unauthorized access

part.name: statement
part.p: The hardware, software (e.g., firmware, operating systems, applications), and services of physical and virtual platforms are managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect their confidentiality, integrity, and availability

part.name: statement
part.p: Configuration management practices are established and applied

part.name: example
part.p: Establish, test, deploy, and maintain hardened baselines that enforce the organization's cybersecurity policies and provide only essential capabilities (i.e., principle of least functionality)

part.name: example
part.p: Review all default configuration settings that may potentially impact cybersecurity when installing or upgrading software

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor implemented software for deviations from approved baselines

part.name: statement
part.p: Software is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk

part.name: example
part.p: Perform routine and emergency patching within the timeframes specified in the vulnerability management plan

part.name: example
part.p: Update container images, and deploy new container instances to replace rather than update existing instances

part.name: example
part.p: Replace end-of-life software and service versions with supported, maintained versions

part.name: example
part.p: Uninstall and remove unauthorized software and services that pose undue risks

part.name: example
part.p: Uninstall and remove any unnecessary software components (e.g., operating system utilities) that attackers might misuse

part.name: example
part.p: Define and implement plans for software and service end-of-life maintenance support and obsolescence

part.name: statement
part.p: Hardware is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk

part.name: example
part.p: Replace hardware when it lacks needed security capabilities or when it cannot support software with needed security capabilities

part.name: example
part.p: Define and implement plans for hardware end-of-life maintenance support and obsolescence

part.name: example
part.p: Perform hardware disposal in a secure, responsible, and auditable manner

part.name: statement
part.p: Log records are generated and made available for continuous monitoring

part.name: example
part.p: Configure all operating systems, applications, and services (including cloud-based services) to generate log records

part.name: example
part.p: Configure log generators to securely share their logs with the organization's logging infrastructure systems and services

part.name: example
part.p: Configure log generators to record the data needed by zero-trust architectures

part.name: statement
part.p: Installation and execution of unauthorized software are prevented

part.name: example
part.p: When risk warrants it, restrict software execution to permitted products only or deny the execution of prohibited and unauthorized software

part.name: example
part.p: Verify the source of new software and the software's integrity before installing it

part.name: example
part.p: Configure platforms to use only approved DNS services that block access to known malicious domains

part.name: example
part.p: Configure platforms to allow the installation of organization-approved software only

part.name: statement
part.p: Secure software development practices are integrated, and their performance is monitored throughout the software development life cycle

part.name: example
part.p: Protect all components of organization-developed software from tampering and unauthorized access

part.name: example
part.p: Secure all software produced by the organization, with minimal vulnerabilities in their releases

part.name: example
part.p: Maintain the software used in production environments, and securely dispose of software once it is no longer needed

part.name: statement
part.p: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

part.name: statement
part.p: Removable media is protected and its use restricted according to policy

part.name: statement
part.p: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

part.name: statement
part.p: Communications and control networks are protected

part.name: statement
part.p: Mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap) are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations

part.name: overview
part.p: Possible cybersecurity attacks and compromises are found and analyzed

part.name: statement
part.p: Anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events are analyzed to characterize the events and detect cybersecurity incidents

part.name: statement
part.p: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed

part.name: statement
part.p: Potentially adverse events are analyzed to better understand associated activities

part.name: example
part.p: Use security information and event management (SIEM) or other tools to continuously monitor log events for known malicious and suspicious activity

part.name: example
part.p: Utilize up-to-date cyber threat intelligence in log analysis tools to improve detection accuracy and characterize threat actors, their methods, and indicators of compromise

part.name: example
part.p: Regularly conduct manual reviews of log events for technologies that cannot be sufficiently monitored through automation

part.name: example
part.p: Use log analysis tools to generate reports on their findings

part.name: statement
part.p: Information is correlated from multiple sources

part.name: example
part.p: Constantly transfer log data generated by other sources to a relatively small number of log servers

part.name: example
part.p: Use event correlation technology (e.g., SIEM) to collect information captured by multiple sources

part.name: example
part.p: Utilize cyber threat intelligence to help correlate events among log sources

part.name: statement
part.p: The estimated impact and scope of adverse events are understood

part.name: example
part.p: Use SIEMs or other tools to estimate impact and scope, and review and refine the estimates

part.name: example
part.p: A person creates their own estimates of impact and scope

part.name: statement
part.p: Incident alert thresholds are established

part.name: statement
part.p: Information on adverse events is provided to authorized staff and tools

part.name: example
part.p: Use cybersecurity software to generate alerts and provide them to the security operations center (SOC), incident responders, and incident response tools

part.name: example
part.p: Incident responders and other authorized personnel can access log analysis findings at all times

part.name: example
part.p: Automatically create and assign tickets in the organization's ticketing system when certain types of alerts occur

part.name: example
part.p: Manually create and assign tickets in the organization's ticketing system when technical staff discover indicators of compromise

part.name: statement
part.p: Cyber threat intelligence and other contextual information are integrated into the analysis

part.name: example
part.p: Securely provide cyber threat intelligence feeds to detection technologies, processes, and personnel

part.name: example
part.p: Securely provide information from asset inventories to detection technologies, processes, and personnel

part.name: example
part.p: Rapidly acquire and analyze vulnerability disclosures for the organization's technologies from suppliers, vendors, and third-party security advisories

part.name: statement
part.p: Incidents are declared when adverse events meet the defined incident criteria

part.name: example
part.p: Apply incident criteria to known and assumed characteristics of activity in order to determine whether an incident should be declared

part.name: example
part.p: Take known false positives into account when applying incident criteria

part.name: statement
part.p: Assets are monitored to find anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events

part.name: statement
part.p: Networks and network services are monitored to find potentially adverse events

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor DNS, BGP, and other network services for adverse events

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor wired and wireless networks for connections from unauthorized endpoints

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor facilities for unauthorized or rogue wireless networks

part.name: example
part.p: Compare actual network flows against baselines to detect deviations

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor network communications to identify changes in security postures for zero trust purposes

part.name: statement
part.p: The physical environment is monitored to find potentially adverse events

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor logs from physical access control systems (e.g., badge readers) to find unusual access patterns (e.g., deviations from the norm) and failed access attempts

part.name: example
part.p: Review and monitor physical access records (e.g., from visitor registration, sign-in sheets)

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor physical access controls (e.g., locks, latches, hinge pins, alarms) for signs of tampering

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor the physical environment using alarm systems, cameras, and security guards

part.name: statement
part.p: Personnel activity and technology usage are monitored to find potentially adverse events

part.name: example
part.p: Use behavior analytics software to detect anomalous user activity to mitigate insider threats

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor logs from logical access control systems to find unusual access patterns and failed access attempts

part.name: example
part.p: Continuously monitor deception technology, including user accounts, for any usage

part.name: statement
part.p: Malicious code is detected

part.name: statement
part.p: Unauthorized mobile code is detected

part.name: statement
part.p: External service provider activities and services are monitored to find potentially adverse events

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor remote and onsite administration and maintenance activities that external providers perform on organizational systems

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor activity from cloud-based services, internet service providers, and other service providers for deviations from expected behavior

part.name: statement
part.p: Monitoring for unauthorized personnel, connections, devices, and software is performed

part.name: statement
part.p: Vulnerability scans are performed

part.name: statement
part.p: Computing hardware and software, runtime environments, and their data are monitored to find potentially adverse events

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor email, web, file sharing, collaboration services, and other common attack vectors to detect malware, phishing, data leaks and exfiltration, and other adverse events

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor authentication attempts to identify attacks against credentials and unauthorized credential reuse

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor software configurations for deviations from security baselines

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor hardware and software for signs of tampering

part.name: example
part.p: Use technologies with a presence on endpoints to detect cyber health issues (e.g., missing patches, malware infections, unauthorized software), and redirect the endpoints to a remediation environment before access is authorized

part.name: statement
part.p: Roles and responsibilities for detection are well defined to ensure accountability

part.name: statement
part.p: Detection activities comply with all applicable requirements

part.name: statement
part.p: Detection processes are tested

part.name: statement
part.p: Event detection information is communicated

part.name: statement
part.p: Detection processes are continuously improved

part.name: overview
part.p: Actions regarding a detected cybersecurity incident are taken

part.name: statement
part.p: Investigations are conducted to ensure effective response and support forensics and recovery activities

part.name: statement
part.p: Notifications from detection systems are investigated

part.name: statement
part.p: The impact of the incident is understood

part.name: statement
part.p: Analysis is performed to establish what has taken place during an incident and the root cause of the incident

part.name: example
part.p: Determine the sequence of events that occurred during the incident and which assets and resources were involved in each event

part.name: example
part.p: Attempt to determine what vulnerabilities, threats, and threat actors were directly or indirectly involved in the incident

part.name: example
part.p: Analyze the incident to find the underlying, systemic root causes

part.name: example
part.p: Check any cyber deception technology for additional information on attacker behavior

part.name: statement
part.p: Incidents are categorized consistent with response plans

part.name: statement
part.p: Processes are established to receive, analyze and respond to vulnerabilities disclosed to the organization from internal and external sources (e.g. internal testing, security bulletins, or security researchers)

part.name: statement
part.p: Actions performed during an investigation are recorded, and the records' integrity and provenance are preserved

part.name: example
part.p: Require each incident responder and others (e.g., system administrators, cybersecurity engineers) who perform incident response tasks to record their actions and make the record immutable

part.name: example
part.p: Require the incident lead to document the incident in detail and be responsible for preserving the integrity of the documentation and the sources of all information being reported

part.name: statement
part.p: Incident data and metadata are collected, and their integrity and provenance are preserved

part.name: example
part.p: Collect, preserve, and safeguard the integrity of all pertinent incident data and metadata (e.g., data source, date/time of collection) based on evidence preservation and chain-of-custody procedures

part.name: statement
part.p: An incident's magnitude is estimated and validated

part.name: example
part.p: Review other potential targets of the incident to search for indicators of compromise and evidence of persistence

part.name: example
part.p: Automatically run tools on targets to look for indicators of compromise and evidence of persistence

part.name: statement
part.p: Response activities are coordinated with internal and external stakeholders as required by laws, regulations, or policies

part.name: statement
part.p: Personnel know their roles and order of operations when a response is needed

part.name: statement
part.p: Internal and external stakeholders are notified of incidents

part.name: example
part.p: Follow the organization's breach notification procedures after discovering a data breach incident, including notifying affected customers

part.name: example
part.p: Notify business partners and customers of incidents in accordance with contractual requirements

part.name: example
part.p: Notify law enforcement agencies and regulatory bodies of incidents based on criteria in the incident response plan and management approval

part.name: statement
part.p: Information is shared with designated internal and external stakeholders

part.name: example
part.p: Securely share information consistent with response plans and information sharing agreements

part.name: example
part.p: Voluntarily share information about an attacker's observed TTPs, with all sensitive data removed, with an Information Sharing and Analysis Center (ISAC)

part.name: example
part.p: Notify HR when malicious insider activity occurs

part.name: example
part.p: Regularly update senior leadership on the status of major incidents

part.name: example
part.p: Follow the rules and protocols defined in contracts for incident information sharing between the organization and its suppliers

part.name: example
part.p: Coordinate crisis communication methods between the organization and its critical suppliers

part.name: statement
part.p: Coordination with stakeholders occurs consistent with response plans

part.name: statement
part.p: Voluntary information sharing occurs with external stakeholders to achieve broader cybersecurity situational awareness

part.name: statement
part.p: Response plans incorporate lessons learned

part.name: statement
part.p: Response strategies are updated

part.name: statement
part.p: Responses to detected cybersecurity incidents are managed

part.name: statement
part.p: The incident response plan is executed in coordination with relevant third parties once an incident is declared

part.name: example
part.p: Detection technologies automatically report confirmed incidents

part.name: example
part.p: Request incident response assistance from the organization's incident response outsourcer

part.name: example
part.p: Designate an incident lead for each incident

part.name: example
part.p: Initiate execution of additional cybersecurity plans as needed to support incident response (for example, business continuity and disaster recovery)

part.name: statement
part.p: Incident reports are triaged and validated

part.name: example
part.p: Preliminarily review incident reports to confirm that they are cybersecurity-related and necessitate incident response activities

part.name: example
part.p: Apply criteria to estimate the severity of an incident

part.name: statement
part.p: Incidents are categorized and prioritized

part.name: example
part.p: Further review and categorize incidents based on the type of incident (e.g., data breach, ransomware, DDoS, account compromise)

part.name: example
part.p: Prioritize incidents based on their scope, likely impact, and time-critical nature

part.name: example
part.p: Select incident response strategies for active incidents by balancing the need to quickly recover from an incident with the need to observe the attacker or conduct a more thorough investigation

part.name: statement
part.p: Incidents are escalated or elevated as needed

part.name: example
part.p: Track and validate the status of all ongoing incidents

part.name: example
part.p: Coordinate incident escalation or elevation with designated internal and external stakeholders

part.name: statement
part.p: The criteria for initiating incident recovery are applied

part.name: example
part.p: Apply incident recovery criteria to known and assumed characteristics of the incident to determine whether incident recovery processes should be initiated

part.name: example
part.p: Take the possible operational disruption of incident recovery activities into account

part.name: statement
part.p: Activities are performed to prevent expansion of an event and mitigate its effects

part.name: statement
part.p: Incidents are contained

part.name: example
part.p: Cybersecurity technologies (e.g., antivirus software) and cybersecurity features of other technologies (e.g., operating systems, network infrastructure devices) automatically perform containment actions

part.name: example
part.p: Allow incident responders to manually select and perform containment actions

part.name: example
part.p: Allow a third party (e.g., internet service provider, managed security service provider) to perform containment actions on behalf of the organization

part.name: example
part.p: Automatically transfer compromised endpoints to a remediation virtual local area network (VLAN)

part.name: statement
part.p: Incidents are eradicated

part.name: example
part.p: Cybersecurity technologies and cybersecurity features of other technologies (e.g., operating systems, network infrastructure devices) automatically perform eradication actions

part.name: example
part.p: Allow incident responders to manually select and perform eradication actions

part.name: example
part.p: Allow a third party (e.g., managed security service provider) to perform eradication actions on behalf of the organization

part.name: statement
part.p: Newly identified vulnerabilities are mitigated or documented as accepted risks

part.name: statement
part.p: Response plan is executed during or after an incident

part.name: overview
part.p: Assets and operations affected by a cybersecurity incident are restored

part.name: statement
part.p: Restoration activities are coordinated with internal and external parties

part.name: statement
part.p: Public relations are managed

part.name: statement
part.p: Reputation is repaired after an incident

part.name: statement
part.p: Recovery activities and progress in restoring operational capabilities are communicated to designated internal and external stakeholders

part.name: example
part.p: Securely share recovery information, including restoration progress, consistent with response plans and information sharing agreements

part.name: example
part.p: Regularly update senior leadership on recovery status and restoration progress for major incidents

part.name: example
part.p: Follow the rules and protocols defined in contracts for incident information sharing between the organization and its suppliers

part.name: example
part.p: Coordinate crisis communication between the organization and its critical suppliers

part.name: statement
part.p: Public updates on incident recovery are shared using approved methods and messaging

part.name: example
part.p: Follow the organization's breach notification procedures for recovering from a data breach incident

part.name: example
part.p: Explain the steps being taken to recover from the incident and to prevent a recurrence

part.name: statement
part.p: Recovery plans incorporate lessons learned

part.name: statement
part.p: Recovery strategies are updated

part.name: statement
part.p: Restoration activities are performed to ensure operational availability of systems and services affected by cybersecurity incidents

part.name: statement
part.p: The recovery portion of the incident response plan is executed once initiated from the incident response process

part.name: example
part.p: Begin recovery procedures during or after incident response processes

part.name: example
part.p: Make all individuals with recovery responsibilities aware of the plans for recovery and the authorizations required to implement each aspect of the plans

part.name: statement
part.p: Recovery actions are selected, scoped, prioritized, and performed

part.name: example
part.p: Select recovery actions based on the criteria defined in the incident response plan and available resources

part.name: example
part.p: Change planned recovery actions based on a reassessment of organizational needs and resources

part.name: statement
part.p: The integrity of backups and other restoration assets is verified before using them for restoration

part.name: example
part.p: Check restoration assets for indicators of compromise, file corruption, and other integrity issues before use

part.name: statement
part.p: Critical mission functions and cybersecurity risk management are considered to establish post-incident operational norms

part.name: example
part.p: Use business impact and system categorization records (including service delivery objectives) to validate that essential services are restored in the appropriate order

part.name: example
part.p: Work with system owners to confirm the successful restoration of systems and the return to normal operations

part.name: example
part.p: Monitor the performance of restored systems to verify the adequacy of the restoration

part.name: statement
part.p: The integrity of restored assets is verified, systems and services are restored, and normal operating status is confirmed

part.name: example
part.p: Check restored assets for indicators of compromise and remediation of root causes of the incident before production use

part.name: example
part.p: Verify the correctness and adequacy of the restoration actions taken before putting a restored system online

part.name: statement
part.p: The end of incident recovery is declared based on criteria, and incident-related documentation is completed

part.name: example
part.p: Prepare an after-action report that documents the incident itself, the response and recovery actions taken, and lessons learned

part.name: example
part.p: Declare the end of incident recovery once the criteria are met
